tossups.question: To oxidize this compound, Linic Lab at the University of Michigan used silver nanoparticles coated in platinum as a plasmonic catalyst. Oxidation of this compound and nitrogen-containing compounds is inhibited by manganese derived from MMT. An iridium atom bonded to two iodines and two equivalents of this molecule is the active catalyst in the Cativa process. This is the heavier of the two major components of both water gas and syngas. In a (*) blast furnace, this compound is used to reduce iron oxide to pure iron. Meat can be packed with this gas in order to maintain its bright red color. This compound is a byproduct of combustion reactions in low oxygen environments such as in car engines. For 10 points, name this toxic diatomic gas that binds hemoglobin 230 times stronger than oxygen.
tossups.answer: carbon monoxide [or CO; do not accept “CO2”] <JL, Chem>

tossups.question: This historical period is profiled in a novel about a man who lives off oranges in the Bunker Hill hotel, the second novel in the “Bandini Quartet” by John Fante. The line “men who have created new fruits in the world cannot create a system whereby their fruits may be eaten” is spoken while living at Weedpatch during this historical period, which is profiled in a novel about the alcoholic Francis Phelan. William Kennedy’s (*) Ironweed is set during this period of time, as is a novel that ends with a sick man being breastfed by a woman who gave birth to the stillborn child of Connie Rivers. Rose of Sharon appears in a novel set during this period in which a strike leads to the death of faithless preacher Jim Casy. For 10 points, The Grapes of Wrath depicts what economic downturn?
tossups.answer: The Great Depression [accept the 1930s; prompt on less specific answers like 20th century] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: In August 2017, it was revealed the UAE gave 20 million dollars to one of these institutions in secret in order to counter “egregious misperceptions.” A comprehensive directory of these institutions is provided by the “Go To” index reports of the University of Pennsylvania’s TTCSP initiative, which ranks them. Thanks to pressure from Google, Barry Lynn was recently fired from one of these organizations headed by Anne-Marie Slaughter. (*) Tyler Cowen heads one of these institutions sponsored by George Mason University called the Mercatus Center. Both left-wing and right-wing critics of these institutions argue that many are effectively now partisan advocacy organizations, citing examples like the Center for American Progress. For 10 points, identify these alliteratively-named nonprofit research groups, such as the Brookings Institution.
tossups.answer: think tanks [prompt on research institutes or policy institutes or research foundations by asking “we’re looking for a specific broad term”] <WA, Other>

tossups.question: A ruler with this name established his country’s first printing house, which the English ambassador Giles Fletcher claimed was burned down by angry scribes. A 14th-century ruler with this name used his great wealth to expand his domain to include towns like Beloozero [beh-luh-OH-zeh-ruh] and Uglich [OO-glitch]. A lack of Polish reinforcements convinced a khan not to attack a ruler with this name camped on the Ugra River, an event considered to have ended the (*) Tatar Yoke. A ruler with this name fought the Livonian War; his father of the same name was the first to call himself tsar. The most famous ruler of this name called the first Zemsky Sobor and formed the Oprichnina to police and terrorize the people. For 10 points, what is this name of several Muscovite rulers, including one with the epithet “Terrible”?
tossups.answer: Ivan [if someone insists on saying John or Johannes I guess those are correct translations] <AF, ContHist>

tossups.question: Besides writing about medicine, the late Roman writer Vegetius is best known for writing about this subject, which is the subject of a treatise translated in 1910 by Lionel Giles. An “absolute” form of this subject, dealt with by professionals, is contrasted with a variety of it called “of observation” in an 1832 book criticized by John Keegan for presuming the existence of states. Another book on this subject consists of thirteen chapters, the eleventh of which deals with the “Nine Situations,” and notes that “all” of this subject is (*) “based on deception.” Thomas Aquinas introduced three principles to refine Saint Augustine’s theory of a “just” form of this concept, which is the subject of a treatise by Karl von Clausewitz. For 10 points, Sun Tzu wrote about the “Art of” what?
tossups.answer: warfare [or bellum; accept The Art of War; accept anything involving the military] <WA, PhilO>

tossups.question: This accuracy of this artist’s workshop in depicting Jerusalem in its The Three Marys at the Tomb suggests that he may have visited the Middle East. The phrase “Loyal Memory” is etched in stone beneath a man wearing a green chaperon in this man’s Leal Souvenir. Over 20 paintings by this artist contain a pun on the Greek spelling of his name, meaning “As I Can.” Mary wears two gold rings and a flowing red dress in both this artist’s (*) Dresden Triptych and Lucca Madonna, which feature his wife Marguerite. This artist created a noted self-portrait in a red turban. A convex mirror in a work by this artist has a set of medallions depicting the Passion of Christ around its edge, and accompanies a small furry dog at the bottom of a merchant’s feet. For 10 points, name this painter of the Arnolfini Wedding.
tossups.answer: Jan van Eyck [generously accept Hubert van Eyck] <EX, Painting>

tossups.question: The phrase “House of” [this god] referred both the sky and the name of a goddess whose statue was carried to his cult center at Hierakonpolis [hye-rah-KON-puh-lis]. At a party, a different god tried to get this deity drunk and rape him, but this god caught the aggressor’s semen in his hand, which was later cut off with a copper knife. This god was conceived when his mother used a golden (*) phallus to have sex with her dead husband. A new body part was fashioned for this god by the moon god Khonsu during a fight in which he was healed with milk. His son Imsety protected the liver as one of the four canopic [kuh-NAH-pic] jars. This god lost his left eye, the wedjat [WEH-jaht], during his eighty-year fight against his father’s killer Seth. For 10 points, name this falcon-headed son of Osiris.
tossups.answer: Horus <WA, Myth>

tossups.question: The asymptotic runtime of algorithms of this type are calculated in the Akra–Bazzi theorem, which generalizes the master theorem. Static padding can be used to enhance a matrix multiplication algorithm of this type named for Strassen. Trigonometric constants called twiddle factors are used in the Cooley–Tukey FFT algorithm of this type. (*) Mergesort and quicksort differ in whether the “divide” or “conquer” steps of this type of algorithm are trivial. Algorithms of this type are proven correct via induction from base cases. The factorial and Fibonacci functions can be implemented using functions of this type with tail calls. For 10 points, name this property of a function that calls itself.
tossups.answer: recursive [or recursion; accept divide and conquer until read] <JL, CompSci>

tossups.question: In T. S. Eliot’s “The Dry Salvages,” this location is said to be “sullen” and “untamed” and is called a “strong brown God.” A work titled for this location includes the section “Frescoes from the Past” and recounts its narrator’s time under Horace Bixby as a “cub.” A deaf-mute uses April Fool’s day jokes to trick people journeying along this geographic feature in the novel The Confidence-Man by Herman Melville. The author’s experience as a pilot is detailed in an 1883 work titled for (*) “Life on” this location. A journey along it is joined by a pair of con artists who pose as King Louis XVII and the Duke of Nonesuch and begins after a slave runs away from Mrs. Watson’s house. For 10 points, name this river that Jim floats down on a raft in Huck Finn.
tossups.answer: Mississippi River [accept river on the first clue and prompt thereafter; accept Life on the Mississippi; accept “Old Man River”] <JM, OtherLit>

tossups.question: This dynasty created a type of province called a zhou as a higher administrative subdivision than the 160 commanderies it controlled. The first known marriage alliances called héqīn [huh-cheen] occurred during this dynasty’s rule, leading to ten of their princesses being married off to foreign holders of the title chányú. Its founder came to power after overcoming Xiàng Yǔ’s [shyong yoo’s] state of (*) Chu. It began the practice of monopolizing salt and iron production and frequently warred with the nomadic Xiōngnú [shyung-noo]. Its decline was sparked by the Yellow Turban Rebellion. For 10 points, name this Chinese dynasty founded by Liú Bāng that was in power from 206 BC to 220 CE.
tossups.answer: Hàn Dynasty <AF, WorldHist>

tossups.question: A subset of these cells includes an “off switch” protein targeted by the melanoma drug ipilimumab. Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin [CAL-sih-NEUR-in], which normally dephosphorylates a transcription factor named for these cells, called NFAT [N-fat]. These are the most common cells that possess LFA-1 [L-F-A-one], a protein involved in forming a specialized type of synapse with APCs [A-P-C’s]. These cells have a namesake receptor that interacts with the co-receptor CD3. These cells mature in an organ that (*) atrophies in adulthood. Two major classes of these cells are defined by having the proteins CD4 or CD8, making them “helper” or “killer” ones respectively. For 10 points, what immune cells are named for developing in the thymus?
tossups.answer: T cells [or T lymphocytes; accept specific types of T cells such as: helper or CD4-positive, killer or cytotoxic or CD8-positive, or naive] <RY, Biology>

tossups.question: As a child, this person was ordered to prepare a meal that replenished itself shortly before being chosen for leadership. Both this man and a rebel opponent were instructed to cease fighting after a conference held at Adhruh [ah-THROO]. This man was given a title that means “father of dust,” although his supporters regard it as a badge of honor. In order to defend himself at Khaybar, this man used an impossibly heavy door as a shield. His wife names a caliphate that was based in (*) Egypt. Muawiyah I declared himself to be this man’s successor and ended the First Fitna after this man was killed by the Kharijites. This man’s son Husayn was martyred at the Battle of Karbala. For 10 points, name this husband of Fatimah, who is considered by Shia Muslims to be the first Imam and the only legitimate Rashidun caliph.
tossups.answer: Ali ibn Abi Talib <VC, Rel>

tossups.question: The Indian sage Calanus reportedly told a man “We shall meet in” [this city] before immolating himself. A king of this city angered priests by moving to the oasis of Tayma for ten years. A historian from this city named Berossus was a priest at the Esagila temple. A man who died in this city left his empire “to the strongest.” An alliance was made between this city and Cyaxares of Media under (*) Nabopolassar, which enabled this city’s restoration to prominence under the Chaldean dynasty. This city’s king Nabonidus left his son Belshazzar in charge before it was conquered by Cyrus the Great, Alexander the Great died in this city, where the principle of “an eye for an eye” was used for a law code. For 10 points, name this city ruled by Hammurabi.
tossups.answer: Babylon [or Babili; accept Babylonia] <RY, Ancient>

tossups.question: Walt Disney’s Fantasia replaces the interpreters of a dance from this work with flowers. That lively G major dance from this work has its first 16 measures played only by violins, which are later joined by the orchestra including tambourines. The name of a character in this work was changed to Marie in the production that established its worldwide popularity, which was made in 1954 with Maria Tallchief choreographed by (*) George Balanchine. In a 1919 production by Alexander Gorsky, two of this ballet’s female characters were combined and the Cavalier was eliminated. A dance in this ballet is introduced by a celesta, followed by notes played by the bassoon. For 10 points, name this ballet whose title character duels the Mouse King with music by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky.
tossups.answer: The Nutcracker <WA, OAudArt>

tossups.question: This author asked the question “At what hour do the hours end?” in a poem that notes “I too await the coming of my hour, I exist” titled “The Clerk’s Vision.” A poem by this author that states “I go among your body as among the world” has a structure based on the synodic period of Venus. In that surrealist poem by this author, the last six lines are the same as the first six lines, which describe a river that “advances and retreats” and is “winding forever.” This author collected prose poems in (*) Eagle or Sun? A 584-line poem by this author opens with “a willow of crystal, a poplar of water” and is titled for an Aztec relic. For 10 points, what author wrote the poem “Sun Stone” and the essays in The Labyrinth of Solitude about the heritage of his native Mexico?
tossups.answer: Octavio Paz <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: This scientist co-names a device that measures sunlight intensity using a glass sphere to focus the light to burn a card; he names that “recorder” with Campbell. This scientist and an alphabetically prior man co-name an equation derived from Chapman–Enskog expansion of the Boltzmann equation. A quantity named for this scientist is set equal to the sum of the gravitational and electrostatic forces to determine the fundamental charge in the Millikan oil drop experiment; that quantity equals 6 pi r v times (*) viscosity and is called his drag. This scientist is the alphabetically latter namesake of an equation whose viscous term can be ignored in favor of the inertia term at low Reynolds number. For 10 points, name this physicist who co-names the central equation of fluid dynamics with Navier.
tossups.answer: George Gabriel Stokes [accept Campbell–Stokes recorder, Stokes parameters, Stokes drag, etc.] <JL, Phys>

tossups.question: Gunnar Svaetichin [svai-TEE-chin] provided the first biological evidence for one theory of this phenomenon and gives his name to its S-potentials. The Purkinje [purr-KIN-jee] effect explains a shift in this phenomenon from day to night time. It’s not motivation, but Ewald Hering developed a model of this phenomenon with anabolic and catabolic phases known as “opponent-process” theory. An illusion stemming from this phenomenon places a (*) cylindrical object on a checkerboard and is an illustration of its “constancy.” Young and Helmholtz devised a theory of this phenomenon, a common test of which places different numbers within a series of dots. For 10 points, name this sense stemming from rods and cones in the retina, which is partially explained by the trichromatic theory.
tossups.answer: color vision [accept any answer related to perceiving color; prompt on vision or seeing] <JM, SocSci>

tossups.question: A third movement “moto perpetuo” ends Samuel Barber’s 1939 orchestral work of this type, which has been performed by Ruggiero Ricci [roo-JAIR-oh REE-chee]. Henri Vieuxtemps [on-REE vyoo-TAWM] wrote seven works in this genre, including ones named “À Jenő Hubay” [AH YEN-oh HOO-bye] and “Le Grétry.” One of these works written by Mendelssohn in his youth was premiered in 1951 by Yehudi Menuhin; Mendelssohn’s more famous (*) E minor piece of this type revolutionarily had the soloist enter almost immediately. Joseph Joachim [YO-zef YAW-kim] was a frequent dedicatee of these pieces in the 19th century. Beethoven, Brahms, and Tchaikovsky each used D major for their only works in this genre. For 10 points, name these compositions for string soloist and orchestra, exemplified by Vivaldi’s The Four Seasons.
tossups.answer: violin concertos [prompt on concertos] <EX, Music>

tossups.question: This state’s university system was hit by the Sterling Hall bombing in 1970, which was part of a protest movement in which a future mayor named Paul Soglin was injured. A Senator from this state received a significant donation from the sugar lobby, earning him the nickname “The Pepsi-Cola Kid.” A governor of this state who was supported by a group called the “Insurgents” developed its namesake “idea” by implementing many (*) Progressive programs. “Sewer socialism” was pioneered in this state, one of whose Senators was criticized on air by Edward R. Murrow and was asked by Joseph Welch, “have you no sense of decency, sir?” For 10 points, name this state at one point represented in the Senate by Joseph McCarthy and lead by Robert LaFollette from Madison.
tossups.answer: Wisconsin <LS, AmHist>

tossups.question: A character in this novel tests psychological theories by observing a man’s reaction to being yelled at in the street by a painter, with whom he walks a hundred paces in silence. This novel’s protagonist is given a copper cross by a woman who encourages him to kiss the earth in a town square. A man in this novel briefly chats with a soldier designated “Achilles” before he declares that he is going to America, then (*) shoots himself. Its epilogue takes place in a prison hospital, where the protagonist learns to pray in Siberia. This novel’s protagonist is read the story of Lazarus by the prostitute Sonya, who is framed for the theft of a hundred rubles by Luzhin, who seeks to marry Dunya. For 10 points, the pawnbroker Alyona is murdered by Raskolnikov in what Fyodor Dostoevsky novel?
tossups.answer: Crime and Punishment [or Prestupleniye i nakazaniye] <WA, LongFic> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: A character in this work is scolded for using the greeting “Uhuru!” and lives in a cave that he refers to as his “ghetto.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play that features the trickster god Eshu. In it, a man states “Call me X” because his “name has been stolen.”
A Tempest is an adaptation of Shakespeare from a postcolonial perspective by Aimé Césaire, a writer from this Africa-focused movement in Senegal that also included future president Léopold Senghor.
Members of the Négritude movement wrote in this language, common among many North African writers including Albert Camus.

bonuses.leadin: This director’s split-screen film Chelsea Girls, which he created with Paul Morrissey, features many of his “superstars.” For 10 points each:
answers: Campbell’s Soup Cans [accept descriptions of cans that contain soup]
The Last Supper [accept Sixty Last Suppers; accept The Sacrament of the Last Supper (by Salvador Dalí)] <RY, OVisArt>
parts: Name this director who would later be shot by one of his actors, Valerie Solanas. His other art films include Sleep and Empire, which is a silent eight-hour long shot of the Empire State Building.
Warhol’s 32 canvases of these food containers are displayed at the MoMA. They include ones labeled “tomato rice,” “beef,” and “asparagus.”
Warhol’s last artwork consisted of sixty silkscreen prints of this scene, which also makes up his painting The Big C. A dodecahedron appears in a version of this scene in the National Gallery of Art.

bonuses.leadin: This country developed a “dictation test” to exclude unwanted immigrants without outright banning them in order to avoid angering Great Britain. For 10 points each:
answers: China [or Zhongguo; accept the Qing dynasty, I guess]
parts: Name this country that aimed to keep itself “white” through early 20th-century immigration policies and the genocidal “Black War.” Through the 1901 Laborers Act, it deported the majority of its sugar cane workers.
Patrick Moran, the Archbishop of Sydney, fought Australia’s attempts to exclude immigrants from this country. The US passed a similarly-intended “exclusion act” in 1881.

This Prime Minister passed the Migration Act 1966, which dismantled the last of the White Australia policy and anti-Chinese restrictions. In an unrelated conspiracy theory, some alleged that a Chinese submarine picked him up when he disappeared in 1967.

bonuses.leadin: The Landau–Lifshitz–Gilbert equation relates this quantity’s precession to its cross product with the H-field and with its own time derivative. For 10 points each:
answers: curl [accept del-cross or del-X, but do not accept or prompt on a partial answer for either of those]
parts: Name this quantity that equals the difference between the B-field over mu-nought and the H-field. It is the volume density of magnetic dipole moments in a material.

This operation, applied to the magnetization, yields the bound current density due to the magnetization. Faraday’s law states that this operation applied to the E-field equals the negative time derivative of the B-field.
Faraday’s law is among the four that this Scottish physicist grouped together as fundamental equations of electromagnetism. He also came up with a thought experiment about a namesake “demon.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the philosophy of naming things, for 10 points each.
answers: Confucius [or Master Kong; or Kong Fuzi]
parts: This Chinese philosopher and author of the Analects believed that naming things properly, or “rectification of names,” was required to ensure social harmony.
This two-word term introduced by Saul Kripke in Naming and Necessity applies to a name, or a term in general, that always picks out the same thing in every possible world.
This philosopher’s book A System of Logic introduces the distinction of the “connotation” and “denotation” of a name or other referent. With his wife Harriet, he wrote The Subjection of Women.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Steno’s laws, for 10 points each.
answers: gravity [accept gravitational force or force of gravity]
parts: Steno’s law of superposition states that for a sequence of these layers of rock, the closest of them to the surface must be the youngest.

Steno’s law of superposition is supplemented by the law of original horizontality, which results from this fundamental force governing sediment deposit. Uniform values for the strength of this force form the geoid [JEE-oyd].
The law of cross-cutting relationships states that a series of strata must be older than one of these plutons that cuts through them. These are the vertical version of sills.

bonuses.leadin: According to one version of events, this person received the gift of prophecy to make up for being struck blind by Hera. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who spent seven years in the body of a woman after attacking some snakes that were having sex.

This other character from Greek myth asked to be turned into a man after being sexually assaulted by Poseidon. Poseidon also granted this person invulnerable skin, which did not prevent this person from being buried alive by centaurs.
In Ovid’s Metamorphoses, this goddess grants Iphis a sex change. She was identified in Hellenized traditions as the wife of Serapis and in regular Egyptian myth as the wife of Osiris.

bonuses.leadin: About half of the population of this entity consists of internally displaced refugees. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the common name for this “Democratic Federation of Northern Syria.” Currently unrecognized, this pluralistic, multiethnic state has a secular law code that proclaims absolute equality for women.
Rojava is organized into administrative subunits designated with this term, such as the Jazira one. Switzerland consists of a confederation of subunits denoted by this term.
Among the many non-Muslim minorities in Rojava are this Christian ethnic group. Their state, which is governed from Yerevan, has fought Azerbaijan in several conflicts over exclaves.

bonuses.leadin: This politician gave one speech because “I figured you needed to know what a real Texas accent sounds like.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this former Governor of Texas who gave the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, in which she said that George Bush was “born with a silver foot in his mouth.”

In this man’s first nomination acceptance speech, he mentioned a “Golden Age” that would come with the eradication of “war, poverty, and tyranny.” This two-time Democratic presidential candidate declared in a later speech “eggheads of the world, unite” in reference to critiques of his intellectualism.
This man gave the “Cross of Gold” speech at the 1896 Democratic National Convention and defended the Bible in court in the Scopes Monkey trials.

bonuses.leadin: A member of this family leaves home and takes shelter with Captain Cuttle, the owner of a shop called The Wooden Midshipmen. For 10 points each:
answers: Oliver Twist [or Oliver Twist; or, The Parish Boy’s Progress]
Hard Times [or Hard Times: For These Times] <JM, LongFic>
parts: Name this family headed by a merchant named Paul, who neglects his daughter Florence in favor of his sickly son, who is also named Paul. This family appears in the title of a Charles Dickens novel.
The title orphan of this other Dickens novel is born in a warehouse and meets the Artful Dodger.

In this Dickens novel, Thomas Gradgrind is an educator who insists that “Now, what I want, is Facts” and comically asks children to give the definition of a horse. Its title reflects Victorian social conditions.

bonuses.leadin: Raymond Picard, a scholar of this author, wrote the article “New Criticism or New Fraud?” in response to a book on him by Roland Barthes [roh-LAWN BART]. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 17th-century French playwright. This author of the tragedies Athalie [ah-tah-LEE] and Berenice wrote the title role of his play, Andromaque, for actress Therese du Parc.
Racine’s Phèdre was based on this ancient Greek writer’s play Hippolytus. His other tragedies include Medea and The Bacchae.

This Frenchman argued that actors should distance themselves from roles, instead of focusing on emotion, in his essay “Paradox of Acting.” He wrote a philosophical work about the “dream” of mathematician Jean d’Alembert [dall-ahm-BARE].

bonuses.leadin: This man’s book A Memory of Solferino is about when he organized relief for soldiers who were wounded in that battle at the nearby city of Castiglione. For 10 points each:
answers: Victor Emmanuel II [or Vittorio Emanuele II; prompt on partial answer] <RY, ContHist>
parts: Name this man who, together with Frederic Passy, was awarded the first ever Nobel Peace Prize for his humanitarian efforts in 1901.
Dunant’s experience at Solferino inspired him to found this humanitarian organization. Its namesake symbol is derived from the flag of Switzerland.
Solferino was a victory for an alliance of France and Sardinia, which was at the time led by this king, who later became the first king of a unified Italy.

bonuses.leadin: A sunset named after one of these locations was painted in 1926 and currently hangs in the Whitney Museum. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these locations. An old man looks out of a window smoking a cigarette as his wife reads a book in an Edward Hopper painting titled after a “Hotel” by one of these locations.
Edward Hopper is better known for this painting that shows a man chatting with a woman in a diner that has an advertisement for Phillies Cigars.
Two almost-identical looking women sit across from each other and chat in a restaurant in this other Hopper painting.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity equals the product of the activity of the products raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients over the same quantity for the reactants. For 10 points each:
answers: Van ’t Hoff plot [or Van ’t Hoff equation] <JL, Chem>
parts: Name this quantity, symbolized Q, the equivalent of the equilibrium constant for a non-equilibrium reaction.

When the reaction quotient is greater than the equilibrium constant, product is converted to reactants. That is another way of stating this principle, named for a Frenchman, which states that when equilibria are changed, conditions respond to oppose the change.

This plot and its associated equation are used to find the dependence of the equilibrium constant on temperature. It plots the natural log of the equilibrium constant versus one-over-temperature, unlike the Arrhenius plot, which uses rate constants.

bonuses.leadin: The term upvas is used to describe this practice in Jain tradition, and it may take place during the Paryushan festival. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this religious practice, which is called sawm in Islam.
In the Bahá’í Faith, the fast of ‘Ala lasts for this many days. Devout Bahá’ís are required to send this percentage of their wealth to the Universal House of Justice.
Some people observe a vegetarian fast named after this Old Testament character, who refused the royal food of Nebuchadnezzar. This man later survived being thrown to lions, who did not eat him.

bonuses.leadin: A 20th-century composer who used this prayer in a piece written for Rabbi Jakob Sonderling wrote that he wanted to absolve the melody of Bruch’s “cello-sentimentality.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Jewish prayer whose name means “all vows.” It was used as the setting for an 1880 piece for cello and orchestra by Max Bruch.
That composer who didn’t like “cello-sentimentality” was this man, whose Chamber Symphony No. 1 was performed at the Skandalkonzert.

Schoenberg’s serial composition method used rows consisting of this many notes, which equals the sum of the number of black and white keys on a piano per octave. The chromatic scale has this many unique pitches.

bonuses.leadin: This disease is believed to cause the blistering skin condition dermatitis herpetiformis, due to antibodies against the transglutaminase enzyme. For 10 points each:
answers: celiac disease [or celiac sprue; or non-tropical sprue]
parts: What autoimmune disease is caused by an excessive immune response to gliadin?

Because of damage to the villous lining of the small intestine, patients with undiagnosed celiac disease may be temporarily intolerant to this sugar found in milk. In bacteria, its breakdown is controlled by a namesake operon.

IgA [I-G-A] antibodies, a key part of celiac disease, can be secreted in response to this amino acid. In July 2017, the FDA approved this amino acid to treat sickle cell disease, under the trade name Endari. Its symbol is Q.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity is held constant for a Hicksian demand function. For 10 points each:
answers: marginal rate of substitution [or MRS; prompt on marginal rate by asking “of what?”] <WA, SocSci>
parts: Name this economic concept. Its “marginal” variety refers to how much benefit an agent receives from a good, service, or other product.
These economic curves indicate combinations of goods that provide equal amounts of utility for a given agent.

The fact that indifference curves almost always have negative slopes indicates that this value is almost always positive, since this quantity equals the negative slope of the indifference curve at a given point.

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of this poem claims “that age is best which is the first” and warns that “you may forever tarry” once you have lost their prime. For 10 points each:
answers: “To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time”
parts: Name this poem that advises young people to “gather ye rosebuds while ye may.”
“To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time” was penned by this Cavalier poet who compiled poems like “Corinna’s going A-Maying” and “The Argument of His Book” into his poetry collection, Hesperides.

Herrick wrote many poems about this lover of his, including ones about her “clothes,” “petticoat,” and “breasts.” It is unclear who this woman actually is, but, interestingly, she shares the first name of Herrick’s mother. Only first name needed.

bonuses.leadin: This man first came to power with the help of young army officers called tenentes [teh-NEN-chees]. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this President of Brazil in power from 1930 to 1945 and again from 1951 to 1954. His second presidency was ended with his suicide in Catete Palace.

Catete Palace is in this Brazilian city where Petrobras, founded during Vargas’s second term, is also headquartered. An assassination attempt on Carlos Lacerda, a critic of Vargas’s rule, occurred in this city’s Copacabana neighborhood.

Vargas’s first presidency was preceded by the café com leite [cah-FEH com LAY-chee] period where power was largely held at the local level by people with this title. A regime named for people with this title ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974.
